bioghist.p: The Voynich manuscript is an illustrated manuscript in an unknown language, thought to have been written between 1470 and 1500. It is named after the Polish-American book-dealer Wilfrid M. Voynich, who acquired it in 1912. It has been the subject of intense study by cryptographers. In 1921, William Romaine Newbold, a professor of philosophy at the University of Pennsylvania, offered the first decryption of the manuscript, but his work has since been discredited.

scopecontent.p: The collection consists of reproductions of 57 plates from the Voynich manuscript, used by William Newbold for his book The Cipher of Roger Bacon. The plates are hand-colored photostats of some of the plates in the manuscript, which is held by the Beinecke Library at Yale. The collection also includes a list of plates in Newbold's book.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
